Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Focused Ion Beam Scanning Electron Microscope (FIB-SEM) for Large Volume 3 Dimensional Imaging of Whole Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Yale University to implement a state-of-the-art Focused Ion Beam Scanning Electron Microscope (FIB-SEM) system. It provides a powerful new tool to study the 3D structure and function of cells and their organelles - especially those that require high-resolution, yet large volumetric views. It will also allow new correlative studies that bridge the gap between light microscopy (including super-resolution) and electron microscopy. The broader impacts are multifaceted. The instrument will be integrated into the Yale CCMI Electron Microscopy Core Facility and infrastructure created precisely for such multi-user equipment. The instrument will be used to train the next generation of scientists and bioengineers in quantitative imaging, fostering new interdisciplinary research between biological, engineering and physical sciences. Student diversity is a strong focus and will be actively promoted on multiple fronts through established Yale outreach programs. 3D EM datasets will be rendered in a stereoscopic virtual reality (VR) platform so that anyone can voyage into cells. Thus, the large high-resolution volumetric data will not only propel basic science, but also help educate and inspire a broad and diverse audience.

The new FIB-SEM system will enable new scientific research into how cell and tissue structure impacts function, with projects on how neurons communicate, how organelles such as primary cilia, Golgi complex, phagosomes, and the endoplasmic reticulum form and function. The main user group comprises leaders in a broad range of scientific disciplines stretching across the biological sciences, engineering, and computer sciences. The new system will act as a focal point, with faculty members, postdoctoral trainees, and students from different departments interacting and helping each other to reach common imaging and analysis goals. The instrument will be an extremely valuable tool not only for research on intracellular functions, but also for projects that address intercellular communications, such as those that occur in the nervous system and in the immune system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Implementation of FIB-SEM at Yale is having a transformational impact on our structural studies of cells. The possibility of gaining 3D information of whole cellular volume is revealing completely new aspects of cellular organization. This imaging system provides a much-needed research tool for investigators to address their fundamental scientific questions. So far, 15 principal investigators/laboratories across 11 departments at Yale, many of them are from our consortium who supported the grant application, have utilized this FIB-SEM system for their research projects. For example, studies of neuronal processes (De Camilli lab), has revealed novel aspects of ER organization in axons and dendrites; Studies of autophagy (Melia lab), had demonstrated the property of precursors of the autophagic membrane to generate small vesicle that "phase separate" from the surrounding cytoplasm; Studies of protein-sorting mechanism in Golgi apparatus (Rothman Lab), have discovered a complex internal organization of branching channels that are unknown in the past. The finding provides new insight on how the organelle functions in cell.

This NSF funded FIB-SEM system is hosted at the Electron Microscopy Core Facility in the Center for Cellular and Molecular Imaging. Equipped with state-of-the-art technologies and equipment, the facility has a long tradition of providing a wide range of biological EM support and working closely with investigators on their research projects. Thus, the FIB-SEM is in an ideal environment for educating and training young scientists. After intensive training and practice, a research scientist and assistant have made significant progress on sample preparation and developed various imaging methods for FIB-SEM imaging and data processing. Currently, we not only can perform FIB-SEM and high-resolution SEM imaging with tissues and cells, we also can correlate the FIB-SEM operation with  fluorescence imaging studies. In addition, we have offered outreach educational tours for local college students and participated the state science fairs for local high school students. These activities are commeasured with NSF's education and diversity aims and add synergy with existing programs at Yale.
